entry.et: Middle English thoume, thoumbe, from Old English thūma; akin to Old High German thūmo thumb, Latin tumēre to swell

def.dt: :the short thick digit of the human hand that is analogous in position to the big toe and differs from the other fingers in having only two phalanges, allowing greater freedom of movement, and being opposable to each of them
:a corresponding digit in lower animals
:the part of a glove or mitten that covers the thumb
:a convex molding :ovolo
:extremely awkward or clumsy
:under control :in a state of subservience her father did not have her that much under his thumb Hamilton Basso
:to leaf through (pages) with the thumb :turn
:to soil or wear by or as if by repeated thumbing a badly thumbed book
:to request or obtain (a ride) in a passing automobile by signaling with the thumb
:to turn over pages thumb through a book
:to travel by thumbing rides :hitchhike thumbed across the country
:to place the thumb at one's nose and extend the fingers as a gesture of scorn or defiance
:to express disdain or defiance thumb their nose at opulence Sales Management
:a series of usually labeled notches cut in the fore edge of a book (as a dictionary) to facilitate reference
:mbira
:an unusual ability to make plants grow

entry.et: earlier hop on my thumb, imperative issued to one supposedly small enough to be held in the hand

def.dt: :a very small person
:a widely distributed weedy annual herb (Polygonum persicaria) of the buckwheat family that has large lanceolate leaves often with a blackish blotch suggesting a thumbprint
:any of several small freshwater spiny-finned sculpins (genus Cottus) of Europe and North America
:a method of procedure based on experience and common sense
:a general principle regarded as roughly correct but not intended to be scientifically accurate
:a legendary English dwarf
:a dwarf type, race, or individual
